isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - CATERPILLAR 3176 - SYSTEM COMPONENTS AND OPERATION - KYSOR ENGINE SHUTDOWN

svcprocinfo.para: On vehicles equipped with the Kysor system, battery voltage to power the ECM is controlled by the Run Relay, which is in turn controlled by the Kysor system alarmstat (engine coolant temperature switch) and surestat (engine oil pressure switch) and the Kysor Control Module (30-second automatic override).
The three primary components of the Kysor system are:

svcsubproc.title: Kysor Control Module
svcsubproc.para: The Kysor Control Module is a time delay switch that remains closed for approximately 30 seconds after the engine is started and the start switch is released. Ignition current from J1 flows through the control module contacts (1 to 3) and on circuit 97A to activate the Run Relay. Activating the Run Relay allows battery current to flow through the relay contacts (30 to 87) and through G4 fuse (15 amp) to the ECM (terminal 1). Normally after 30 seconds of engine operation, the oil pressurestat has closed and control of the Run Relay is through the pressurestat and the alarmstat on circuit 19H.

After 30 seconds of engine operation, the Control Module switch will open. If the pressurestat NO (normally open) switch (closed with 3 psi oil pressure) or the NC (normally closed) switch of the alarmstat is not closed, the Run Relay will be deactivated, shutting down the engine.

svcsubproc.title: Pressurestat
svcsubproc.para: The Pressurestat is in the circuit to monitor engine oil pressure. It consists of two sets of contacts which are sensitive to engine oil pressure. One set of contacts, NO (normally open), controls the voltage to the Run Relay control circuit through the C (common) terminal on the alarmstat. The other set of contacts, NC (normally closed), controls the ignition voltage to the Kysor alarm and engine shutdown light.

The NC (normally closed) contacts of the pressurestat control the alarm system. When the ignition switch is in the ON position, the normally closed pressurestat contacts stay closed until the oil pressure exceeds approximately 6 psi, then they open and the alarm is turned off. If the oil pressure drops below approximately 6 psi, the NC (normally closed) contacts will close, sounding the alarm and illuminating the warning light. The alarm will continue to sound until the key switch is turned off.

The NO (normally open) contacts of the pressurestat control the ignition voltage needed to keep the Run Relay activated. With the ignition switch in the ON position, the normally open contacts will close when the engine oil pressure exceeds approximately 3 psi. Ignition voltage will then pass through the pressurestat to the alarmstat to keep the Run Relay activated. If the engine oil pressure drops below 3 psi, the NO (normally open) contacts will open and deactivate the Run Relay, shutting down the engine.

svcsubproc.title: Alarmstat
svcsubproc.para: The Alarmstat also has two sets of contacts. These contacts are sensitive to engine coolant temperature. The NC (normally closed) contacts provide an ignition voltage path from the pressurestat to keep the Run Relay activated. The NO (normally open) contacts control the alarm system in the event operating temperatures are exceeded.

The NC (normally closed) alarmstat contacts that control the Run Relay will remain closed unless the engine coolant temperature exceeds 230 degrees F. If the NC (normally closed) contacts open, the Run Relay will be deactivated, shutting down the engine.

The NO (normally open) alarmstat contacts that control the alarm system will close if engine coolant temperatures exceed 224 degrees F. (six degrees before engine shutdown will occur). If the NO (normally open) contacts close, voltage is applied to the alarm and to the engine shutdown light.

svcsubproc.title: Kysor Engine Shutdown Light
svcsubproc.para: The Kysor shutdown light receives ignition power from J1 when the Pressurestat NC (normally closed) contacts are closed and the alarmstat normally open contacts are closed. The warning light is grounded at J2 (right instrument panel).

In summary, the pressurestat NC (normally closed) contacts will close and activate the alarm system if oil pressure drops to approximately 6 psi. If oil pressure drops to 3 psi, the NO (normally open) contacts will open and deactivate the Run Relay, shutting down the engine. The alarmstat NO (normally open) contacts will close at 224 degrees F. and activate the alarm system. At 230 degrees F., the NC (normally closed) contacts will open and deactivate the Run Relay, shutting down the engine.
